title: Create values.yaml file for OO Containerized on OpenShift
content:
On the bastion node, you need to edit and configure the values.yaml file that comes along with the OO Containerized zip. Helm install uses the values defined inside this file.

Create and configure values.yaml

  1. Create a copy of the values.yaml file in the OO Containerized installation folder (this will ensure that a copy exists permanently).

    cp oo-helm-charts-1.x.x+26.x.x/oo-helm-charts/values/values.yaml <path_to_copied_oo_values_yaml>/values.yaml.backup

  2. Edit the copied values.yaml file using any editor and specify the required values in the file.

This values.yaml file contains critical configuration information. The file must be securely stored and backed up on a regular basis.

Newly added parameters

The below parameters are available for usage and configuration within the values.yaml file starting OO Containerized 23.4: 

  • global.tls.tlsMinVersion
  • global.tls.tlsCiphers
  • oocentral.deployment.maxAllowedVersionGapMsgRecovery
  • oodata-maintenance-and-export.deployment.data.purgeMaxSize

Configurable parameters

The configurable parameters supported by the OO chart are grouped into the following categories:

  • Generic parameters
  • Networking parameters
  • Shared IdM parameters
  • Database parameters
  • Persistence parameters
  • (Optional) Database maintenance retention period
  • Service Management integration parameters
  • Monitoring parameters

Search for and update each parameter described in the below sections as the values.yaml contains other parameters that aren't listed. These parameters either have a default value or don't apply to this scenario.

The values.yaml is in YAML format. Each parameter described below in the format <section1>.<section2>.<section3> is available in the values.yaml file like this:

  section1: 
    section2: 
      section3:

Generic parameters

Parameter Required Description Default Example
acceptEula Yes You must accept EULA to deploy OO false true
global.docker.registry Yes Docker registry where OO docker images are stored. localhost:5000 External registry: registry.example.com:443
global.docker.orgName Yes Name of the docker organization in the registry where OO images exist. hpeswitom hpeswitom
global.securityContext.user Yes

This parameter specifies the operating system user ID that's used to run the process in the container. The value of this parameter and the ID of the File System owner must be the same. 

When using big values, use the value in double quotes. See this GitHub page for more information. For example: user: "1000000"

You can't change this value after installation.

 1999 1000000
global.securityContext.fsGroup Yes

This parameter specifies the operating system group ID that's used to run the process in the container.

When using big values, use the value in double quotes. See the GitHub page for more information. For example: user: "1000000"

You can't change this value after installation.

 1999 2000000
global.tls.tlsMinVersion No

This parameter specifies the minimum TLS version used by the OO components for both server and client.

If the default value is used, TLS 1.3 is used with a fallback to TLS 1.2.

For example, if this parameter is set to "TLSv1.3", only TLS 1.3 protocol will be enabled.

 "TLSv1.2" "TLSv1.2"
global.tls.tlsCiphers No

This parameter specifies the ordered list of TLS enabled cipher suites for both server and client side, used by the OO components.

This parameter value is a YAML array in the following format: ["cipher1", "cipher2"].

 ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_AES_128_CCM_8_SHA256", "TLS_AES_128_CCM_SHA256", "TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256"] ["TLS_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_AES_128_CCM_8_SHA256", "TLS_AES_128_CCM_SHA256", "TLS_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256", "TLS_DHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384", "TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256", "TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305_SHA256"]
global.oo.size No

This parameter controls the resources allocated to each service based on the maximum number of tenants configured. This parameter supports two different configurations: 5 (1-5 tenants) or 20 (6-20 tenants).

Note: Values other than 5 or 20 will be regarded as 5 or 20. For example, if you set this parameter to 3, the resources allocated will support up to 5 tenants. 

 5 20

Networking parameters

These parameters define how the OO application reaches the context of the entire OpenText Service Management suite.  

Parameter Required Description Default Example
global.externalAccessHost Yes

Set the value to the FQDN of the load balancer.

 N/A oo.example.com
global.externalAccessPort Yes Set the value to the listening port on the load balancer for accessing the OO application user interfaces. 9443 9443
global.nginx.httpsPort Yes

This is the https port of the Nginx ingress controller deployed by OO. You must configure the port number you set at this parameter as the target port for routing the OO requests from the load balancer toward the OO Nginx ingress controller.

Set it to a value that doesn't conflict with other applications deployed in the same cluster. For example, if Service Management and OO are deployed in the same cluster, you must set this parameter to a value different than Service Management.
 
If the parameter isn't set, it will take the value of the global.externalAccessPort parameter.

 9443 9443

Shared IdM parameters

OO integrates with the Service Management IdM service. At these parameters, specify the IdM connection details.

Parameter Required Description Default Example
global.idm.idmAuthUrl Yes This is the public URL of the Service Management IdM service. N/A https://<suite-fqdn>:443/idm-service
global.idm.idmTransportUser Yes The IdM transport admin user configured in the suite's IdM service. In the OpenText Service Management suite, the name of this user is idmTransportUser. N/A idmTransportUser
global.idm.superUser Yes The OO integration admin user name created in Create OO integration admin user in suite IdM. N/A oo-integration-admin
global.idm.tenant Yes IdM parent tenant organization name where global.idm.superUser resides. For Service Management and Cloud Management, the name of this organization is sysbo. N/A sysbo

Database parameters

Configure the following parameters to set up the connection to the external database server.

Parameter Required Description Default Example
global.database.type Yes Currently OO supports only PostgreSQL database engines. Set this value to postgresql. N/A postgresql
global.database.host Yes The hostname of the database instance created at the step Prepare external databases for OO. N/A db.host.com
global.database.port Yes Database server port. N/A 5432
global.database.tlsEnabled No Required only when you enable TLS connection for the external database. false true
global.database.oocontroller.dbName Yes OO Controller database name. oocontrollerdb oocontrollerdb
global.database.oocontroller.user Yes OO Controller database user. oocontrollerdbuser oocontrollerdbuser
global.database.ooui.dbName Yes OO Session Manager database name. oouidb oosessionmanagerdb
global.database.ooui.user Yes OO Session Manager database user. oouidbuser oosessionmanagerdbuser
global.database.oocentral.dbName Yes OO Central database name. oocentraldb oocentraldb
global.database.oocentral.user Yes OO Central database user. oocentraldbuser oocentraldbuser
global.database.ooscheduler.dbName Yes OO Scheduler database name. ooschedulerdb ooschedulerdb
global.database.ooscheduler.user Yes OO Scheduler database user. ooschedulerdbuser ooschedulerdbuser
autopass.deployment.database.dbName Yes AutoPass database name. aplsdb aplsdb
autopass.deployment.database.user Yes AutoPass database user. aplsdbuser aplsdbuser
autopass-migration.deployment.database.dbName Yes AutoPass Migration database name, the same as Autopass database name aplsdb aplsdb
autopass-migration.deployment.database.user Yes AutoPass Migration database user, the same as Autopass database user aplsdbuser aplsdbuser

In the values.yaml file, the values for the global.database.ooui.dbName and global.database.ooui.user parameters default to oouidb and oouidbuser. If you create the OO Session Manager database name and database user according to the steps in Create OO database users and database names, then update the values for the global.database.ooui.dbName and global.database.ooui.user parameters as oosessionmanagerdb and oosessionmanagerdbuser.

Persistence parameters

Specify the names of the PVCs created as part of the preparation step Prepare persistent volumes for OO.

Parameter Required Description Example
global.persistence.configVolumeClaim Yes Name of the PVC created for OO configuration files. oo-config-pvc
global.persistence.dataVolumeClaim Yes Name of the PVC created for OO data files. oo-data-pvc
global.persistence.logVolumeClaim Yes Name of the PVC created for OO logs. oo-logs-pvc
global.persistence.dataExportVolumeClaim Yes Name of the PVC created for database exports. oo-data-export-pvc
global.persistence.rasLogVolumeClaim Yes Name of the PVC created for OO RAS logs. oo-ras-logs-pvc

Database maintenance parameters

This section is optional. All parameters described here have default values which are used if not purposely configured.

The OO flows for database purging don't work with the current version of OO. However, to keep the database size under control, OO deploys a Kubernetes cron job at install time, set to run each day at 00:00 GMT. This job aims to purge in the database OO execution data that's older than 365 days.

The data retention period is configurable via the hidden Helm parameter oodata-maintenance-and-export.deployment.data.retentionDays. 

Minimum value is 28, and the value must be in multiples of 14. For example: 28, 42, 56, etc.

You can configure the retention period after installation, by manually editing the Kubernetes job. For more information, see Change OO Database Maintenance Job retention interval.

If you want to configure a different retention interval at OO install time, then run the following command on the Bastion host:

$CDF_HOME/bin/yq e '.oodata-maintenance-and-export.deployment.data.retentionDays = "<desired_amount_of_retention_days>"' -i <path/to/values.yaml>

Where:

$CDF_HOME is the installation directory of OMT.

<desired_amount_of_retention_days> = the retention interval (28, 42, 56, etc.).

<path/to/values.yaml> = the path of the OO values.yaml

Make sure to use the command line tool yq that's part of OMT 2023.05 and not from the OS $PATH.

The version of yq that comes with OMT is 4.6.1, and the syntax of the command doesn't work with older versions of yq.

On top of the retention period, you can configure the purge jobs to automatically trigger and delete data based on tenant schema size by utilizing the oodata-maintenance-and-export.deployment.data.purgeMaxSize parameter. This parameter controls the size limit for all tenants when configured. By default, the parameter is set to (unlimited size) but can be configured to limit the size of the tenant schemas. When enabled this parameter will ignore the retention period and will delete historical data until the tenant schema size is back below the configured limit. 

Parameter Required Description Default Example
oodata-maintenance-and-export.deployment.data.retentionDays No

The OO execution data retention period in days. All data that are older than the number of days specified at this parameter will be automatically purged by the OO data maintenance Kubernetes cron-job.

Minimum value is 28, and the values must be a multiple of 14. For example: 28, 42, 56, etc.

 hidden (not exposed in the values.yaml) 224
oodata-maintenance-and-export.deployment.data.purgeMaxSize No This parameter controls the max size in gigabytes that a tenant's schema is allowed to grow to. After the tenant schema grows beyond the set parameter size purging of historical data will occur, regardless of retention period. 0 200

Service Management integration parameters

Parameter Required Description Default Example
global.smaxFqdn Yes The FQDN and port of the public load balancer for accessing Service Management. N/A smax.example.com:443
caCertificates Conditional

The content of the Service Management CA certificate or the content of the database server's certificate in a base64 encoded form. 

You must keep the original format of the certificate without adding any spaces or changing the indentation.

To get the suite certificates, see Get the suite CA certificate.

The certificates that OO must trust are mandatory, however, providing these certificates via the Helm parameter caCertificates in OO values.yaml is optional.

You can specify these certificates in two ways:

  • At Helm install time via the command line. (Option #1)
  • At OO install time via the Helm parameter caCertificates in values.yaml file. (Option #2)

Regardless of the method you chose, these certificates must be either the server certificates or the root CA that generated the server certificates. In addition, the certificates must be in a PEM format (base64 encoded). 

In comparison:

  • The advantage of Option #1 is that it's faster and easier than Option #2, but it doesn't add the certificate content to the OO values.yaml file.
  • The advantage of Option #2 is that it adds the certificate(s) content to the OO values.yaml file which provides you with a faster way of tracking these certificates at a later point in time, by checking the values.yaml file directly. 

Add the certificates at install time using the CLI

Add the certificates at Helm install time using the --set-file arguments. If you're adding certificates at Helm install time using CLI, ensure to remove the caCertificates parameter from the values.yaml file.

For example: 

helm install [...] --set-file "caCertificates.smax_lb\.crt"=/path/to/smax_lb.crt --set-file "caCertificates.oo_db\.crt"=/path/to/oo_db.crt

Where [...] is a placeholder for other Helm install-related parameters. For more information, see Install OO Containerized.

Make sure not to miss the escape character before the dot in the --set-file argument. For example:"caCertificates.smax_lb\.crt".

You can use multiple --set-file arguments, according to the amount of certificate(s) OO requires to trust.

Add certificates using the Helm parameter

  1. Run the following command to add this parameter in OO values.yaml: 
    $CDF_HOME/bin/yq e '.caCertificates = "placeholder"' -i <path/to/values.yaml>

    Where:
    $CDF_HOME = installation directory of OMT
    <path/to/values.yaml> = the path of the OO values.yaml

    Make sure that:
    You use the command line tool yq that's part of OMT 2023.05 and not from the OS $PATH. The version of yq that comes with OMT is 4.6.1, and the syntax of the command doesn't work with older versions of yq.

  2. Open values.yaml in a text editor, delete "placeholder" from the caCertificates parameter, and specify the content of the certificates as given below: 
    caCertificates:
  smax_lb.crt: |
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFLTCCAxWgAwIBAgIUEgAXHFYWniNO5iq5E7q8UIiLdfswDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    gLMaj435og1CxyQMf5qt+m6DqVXjQR/wPfHUNz6S0aON
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----
  # Only if TLS is enabled with the external database
  oo_db.crt: |
    -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----
    MIIFLTCCAxWgAwIBAgIUEgAXHFYWniNO5iq5E7q8UIiLdfswDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEL
    [...]
    gLMaj435og1CxyQMf5qt+m6DqVXjQR/wPfHUNz6S0aON
    -----END CERTIFICATE-----

    For each certificate, the key index name represents the name of the certificate. In the example, smax_lb.crt is the certificate used for the SMA Application Load Balancer, and oo_db.crt is the certificate used for the external database OO connects to, only if it's configured with a TLS connection. 

    Make sure to use the correct indentation. For example:
    caCertificates is the top-level key index, therefore there is no need for any indentation before the parameter name. 
    smax_lb.crt is a second-level key index, therefore you must use 2 spaces for indentation.
    ----- BEGIN CERTIFICATE ----- is the content of the PEM encoded certificate. Indent each line by 4 spaces.

Monitoring parameters

You can add monitoring support by exposing Prometheus-style metrics from the most critical OO services (OO Controller, OO Central, OO Scheduler, OO Session Manager, and OO Downloader). This helps in troubleshooting various aspects inside the cluster like performance, scalability, and others. Enable monitoring using Prometheus in OMT. After enabling OMT monitoring capability, you must configure OO to deploy the service monitors.

The OO service monitors are deployed when you set the global.prometheus.deployPrometheusConfig user input parameter to true.

Parameter Required Description Default Example
global.prometheus.deployPrometheusConfig No Controls whether to deploy scraping rules through ServiceMonitor objects and alerts through PrometheusRule objects true This input depends on whether you have enabled the monitoring capability.
global.prometheus.deployGrafanaConfig No Controls whether to deploy ConfigMap objects containing Grafana dashboard configurations true ConfigMaps labeled grafana_dashboard: "1" contain dashboard configurations. OMT monitoring solution uploads these dashboards in Grafana. For other monitoring solutions download and upload the dashboards into Grafana manually.
global.prometheus.prometheusSelector.prometheus_config No Defines the label (s) that apply to the scraping rules through ServiceMonitor objects 1 Based on this label, you can include or exclude metrics from Prometheus.
global.prometheus.grafanaSelector.grafana_dashboard No Defines the label(s) that apply to the Grafana dashboard configurations through ConfigMap objects 1 The default label value used by the OMT monitoring solution. For a custom Grafana solution use the appropriate configuration label.
